rules.title: Stylistic Devices (Stilmittel)
rules.description: Literary and rhetorical devices used in formal and creative writing.
examples: Metapher: Er ist ein Löwe im Kampf. (He is a lion in battle.)
Alliteration: Bei Wind und Wetter (In wind and weather)
Hyperbel: Ich habe es dir tausendmal gesagt! (I've told you a thousand times!)
rules.notes: Understanding these enhances comprehension of literature and formal texts.

rules.title: Register: Formal vs. Informal
rules.description: Mastering the appropriate level of formality for different contexts.
examples: Formal: Ich möchte Sie bitten... (I would like to ask you...)
Informal: Kannst du mal... (Can you...)
Formal: Gestatten Sie mir... (Allow me...)
Informal: Darf ich... (May I...)
rules.notes: C2 speakers can seamlessly switch between registers as situations demand.

rules.title: Advanced Idiomatic Expressions
rules.description: Complex idioms and expressions that are deeply rooted in German culture.
examples: Das ist ein zweischneidiges Schwert. (That's a double-edged sword.)
Da liegt der Hund begraben. (That's the crux of the matter.)
Ich verstehe nur Bahnhof. (It's all Greek to me.)
rules.notes: Native-like fluency requires understanding and using idiomatic expressions naturally.

rules.title: Literary Language and Archaisms
rules.description: Understanding and using elevated, poetic, or archaic language in literary contexts.
examples: alsdann (then - archaic)
gar (quite/very - literary): gar nicht (not at all), gar wohl (very well)
jetzig (current - archaic) vs. modern 'jetzige'
ob (whether - in older texts can mean 'if')
weiland (formerly/once upon a time - archaic)
rules.notes: Essential for reading classical literature and understanding historical texts.

rules.title: Advanced Rhetorical Devices
rules.description: Sophisticated rhetorical techniques for persuasive and elegant communication.
examples: Anapher: Ich kam, ich sah, ich siegte. (I came, I saw, I conquered.)
Chiasmus: Nicht weil es schwer ist, wagen wir es nicht, sondern weil wir es nicht wagen, ist es schwer.
Rhetorische Frage: Wer weiß das nicht? (Who doesn't know that?)
Parallelismus: Er spricht viel, aber er sagt wenig. (He speaks much, but says little.)
Antithese: Der Geist ist willig, aber das Fleisch ist schwach.
rules.notes: Used in formal speeches, academic writing, and literary analysis.

rules.title: Regional Variations and Dialects
rules.description: Understanding major dialectal and regional differences in German-speaking areas.
examples: Austrian: Jänner (January) vs. German: Januar
Swiss: parkieren (to park) vs. German: parken
Southern: Samstag vs. Northern: Sonnabend (Saturday)
Austrian: Erdäpfel vs. German: Kartoffeln (potatoes)
Bavarian/Austrian: heuer (this year) vs. Standard: dieses Jahr
rules.notes: C2 speakers recognize and can adapt to regional varieties of German.

rules.title: Irony, Sarcasm, and Subtle Humor
rules.description: Understanding and producing ironic, sarcastic, and nuanced humorous statements.
examples: Das hat ja super geklappt! (said when something failed - That went really well!)
Na, das kann ja heiter werden. (Oh, this is going to be fun. - said sarcastically)
Toll, einfach toll. (Great, just great. - often sarcastic)
Ach was! (Oh really! - can be genuine or sarcastic depending on context)
rules.notes: Requires deep cultural and pragmatic knowledge. Context and intonation are crucial.

rules.title: Semantic Subtleties and Near-Synonyms
rules.description: Distinguishing between near-synonyms and understanding subtle semantic differences.
examples: schauen vs. sehen vs. gucken vs. blicken (all mean 'to look/see' but with nuances)
Haus vs. Gebäude vs. Bau (house vs. building vs. construction)
reden vs. sprechen vs. sich unterhalten (to talk/speak with subtle differences)
Angst vs. Furcht (fear - Angst is more existential, Furcht more concrete)
Arbeit vs. Beruf vs. Tätigkeit (work/job/profession/activity)
rules.notes: C2 level requires choosing the most appropriate word for precise communication.

rules.title: Historical Grammar Forms
rules.description: Understanding older grammatical forms found in classical texts.
examples: Genitiv with articles: des Vaters vs. old: Vaters (father's)
Dative -e ending: im Hause (in the house) vs. modern: im Haus
Older conjugations: du fragst vs. archaic: du fragest
Pronoun 'ihr' as formal address (before Sie): Habt ihr...?
Old subjunctive forms: er käme vs. older: er komme
rules.notes: Important for reading texts from 18th-19th century German literature.

rules.title: Wordplay and Puns
rules.description: Understanding and creating plays on words, double meanings, and puns.
examples: Ich bin nicht ganz bei Trost. (I'm not quite with comfort = I'm not in my right mind)
Sie hat den Bogen raus. (She has the bow out = She's got the hang of it)
Das geht mir auf den Keks. (That goes on my cookie = That gets on my nerves)
Er hat einen Vogel. (He has a bird = He's crazy)
rules.notes: Wordplay is culturally specific and requires deep linguistic and cultural knowledge.

rules.title: Academic Discourse Markers
rules.description: Advanced expressions for structuring academic arguments and research.
examples: diesbezüglich (in this regard)
hieraus folgt/ergibt sich (from this it follows)
daraus lässt sich schließen (from this one can conclude)
im Folgenden wird dargelegt (in the following it will be shown)
unter Berücksichtigung von (taking into account)
es sei darauf hingewiesen, dass (it should be pointed out that)
rules.notes: Essential for academic writing, dissertations, and scholarly publications.

rules.title: Legal and Administrative Language
rules.description: Understanding specialized vocabulary and structures in legal and bureaucratic texts.
examples: gemäß § (according to section)
laut Verordnung (according to regulation)
vorgenannter / besagter (aforementioned)
im Sinne des Gesetzes (within the meaning of the law)
unter Vorbehalt (subject to reservation)
kraft Gesetzes (by force of law)
rules.notes: Necessary for understanding contracts, official documents, and legal texts.

rules.title: Advanced Elliptical Constructions
rules.description: Sophisticated use of ellipsis where elements are deliberately omitted for style or brevity.
examples: Je schneller, desto besser. (The faster, the better - full: je schneller es ist, desto besser ist es)
Kommt Zeit, kommt Rat. (Time will tell - literally: comes time, comes advice)
Ende gut, alles gut. (All's well that ends well)
Was du heute kannst besorgen, (das) verschiebe nicht auf morgen.
rules.notes: Common in proverbs, maxims, and literary writing.

rules.title: Poetic Language and Devices
rules.description: Understanding and using poetic techniques in German literature.
examples: Inversion for emphasis: Kam er doch noch! (He came after all!)
Enjambment (Zeilensprung): line breaks in poetry
Assonanz: repeated vowel sounds
Neologismus: creating new words for effect
Personifikation: Die Sonne lacht. (The sun laughs.)
rules.notes: Essential for analyzing and appreciating German poetry and literature.

rules.title: Advanced False Friends and Cognates
rules.description: Understanding deceptive similarities between German and other languages.
examples: Gift (poison) not gift (Geschenk)
aktuell (current) not actual (tatsächlich)
eventuell (possibly) not eventually (schließlich)
sensibel (sensitive) not sensible (vernünftig)
Gymnasium (academic high school) not gymnasium (Turnhalle)
rules.notes: Important for avoiding common mistakes, especially for English speakers.

rules.title: Euphemisms and Taboo Language
rules.description: Understanding indirect expressions and culturally sensitive topics.
examples: entlassen (let go/fired) instead of 'gefeuert'
einschlafen (fall asleep - euphemism for dying)
die Notdurft verrichten (relieve oneself)
Lebensabend (evening of life - old age)
von uns gegangen (gone from us - died)
rules.notes: Cultural awareness of what topics require indirect language in German culture.

rules.title: Technical and Scientific Precision
rules.description: Precise use of technical terminology across different fields.
examples: Medical: Myokardinfarkt vs. Herzinfarkt (myocardial infarction vs. heart attack)
Scientific: Hypothese vs. Theorie (hypothesis vs. theory - distinct meanings)
Technical: in Kraft treten (come into force/effect)
Philosophy: Sein vs. Dasein vs. Existenz (being/existence with nuanced differences)
rules.notes: C2 speakers can navigate specialized terminology in various professional contexts.

rules.title: Complex Metaphorical Language
rules.description: Extended and mixed metaphors in sophisticated discourse.
examples: am seidenen Faden hängen (hang by a silken thread - be in a precarious situation)
jemanden auf den Arm nehmen (take someone on the arm - pull someone's leg)
die Katze aus dem Sack lassen (let the cat out of the bag)
in den sauren Apfel beißen (bite into the sour apple - bite the bullet)
das Kind mit dem Bade ausschütten (throw the baby out with the bathwater)
rules.notes: Understanding metaphorical thinking in German culture and language.

rules.title: Advanced Communicative Strategies
rules.description: Sophisticated strategies for negotiation, persuasion, and diplomacy.
examples: Hedging: gewissermaßen, sozusagen, quasi (in a way, so to speak)
Diplomatic disagreement: Mit Verlaub, ich sehe das anders. (With respect, I see it differently.)
Softening: möglicherweise, unter Umständen (possibly, under circumstances)
Emphasizing: ausdrücklich, nachdrücklich (expressly, emphatically)
rules.notes: Essential for professional communication, negotiations, and sensitive discussions.

rules.title: Sociolects and Professional Jargon
rules.description: Understanding language variation by social group and profession.
examples: Youth language: krass (awesome/intense), chillen (chill out)
Business jargon: Synergieeffekte (synergy effects), Kernkompetenz (core competency)
Medical: Anamnese (medical history), Differentialdiagnose (differential diagnosis)
IT: downloaden, Software-Update, Firewall
Sports: Eigentor (own goal - also metaphorically)
rules.notes: C2 speakers can identify and use appropriate jargon for different professional contexts.
